quote: Several approaches, including physico-chemical treatment (membrane filtration, coagulation, adsorption and flocculation), biological treatment, and chemical oxidation have been found to effectively remove MB from wastewater.

By applying MEO the degradation of organic pollutants is processed indirectly through a distinctive mediator and membrane, hence metal ions emitted by ionic mediators are no longer produced and secondary environmental problem can be avoided.
A study reported that mediated electrochemical oxidation (MEO) is one of a suitable-processes for destruction of organic pollutant.
Some reports also showed that the application of metal ion catalysts can accelerate the degradation of organic compounds by MEO, thereby producing a better efficiency process.
The degradation process was conducted using Ce(IV) as the ionic mediator and Ag(I) as the ionic catalyst.
In redox system, when Ce(IV) is reduced become Ce(III), MB will be oxidized electrochemically, generate its reducing form.
Studies have shown that the presence of ion catalyst in mediated electrochemical oxidation can accelerate the degradation of organic compounds then enhancing its degradation potential.
We also noticed that the percentage degradation of 250 ppm MB showed similar trend at function of time.
In this experiment, the electrochemical degradation of MB was carried out in a batch system containing H2SO4 solution and Ce(III)/Ce(IV) ionic mediator.
More importantly, the percentage recovery of Ce(IV) ion mediator in this study is higher than 97%, thereby secondary environment pollution can be avoided.
The 100 % of MB degradation at 250 ppm MB was achieved within 30 minutes when 2mM Ag(I) ion catalyst was applied.
Direct and mediated anodic oxidation of organic pollutants.
